subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order
msgSnippet: Hi Ted To be honest, most Americans say the Ah sound for the short/soft o The On sound, as in James Bond, is a British distinction, rarely heard in America
messageBody:
Hi Ted
To be honest, most Americans say the Ah sound for the short/soft "o"
The On sound, as in James Bond, is a British distinction, rarely heard in America
and rarely made except by a native British Speaker..
Regards, Paul V.
P.S. The difference between Ah and Awe is mainly Vowel Length and stress.
Ah is usually found between two consonants in a syllable,
whereas Awe is more likely to end the Syllable or word. 
________________________attached_______________________________
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
From: cowan@...
Date: Mon, 26 Nov 2007 00:26:32 -0500
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Alphabetical Order

Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:

> I've never studied Chinese--I've only observed a thing or two from
> listening to Chinese friends over the years. My guess is that 'l' and
> 'r' are not contrasted for them at all, so they have no clue where to
> place their tongues for the two sounds when they begin to study
> English.

Note that Mandarin Chinese speakers have a perfectly good contrast
between /r/ and /l/. Cantonese Chinese speakers don't, though.

> Likewise, I can only understand what you are saying about Awl and On
> in a theoretical sense. I'm sure I could learn it with practice, but
> it would not be easy. When people say "I can't hear the difference"
> between two sounds, they mean exactly what they say.

There's also only one feature difference: Awl is the low-mid back
rounded vowel, whereas On is the low back rounded vowel. On is
essentially Ah with rounding (and shortened as well).

--
John Cowan http://www.ccil. org/~cowan cowan@...
